Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Origami-Based Extremely-Packed Multistable Pop-Up Design for Medical Masks
Award.AbstractNarration: Intellectual Merits:<br/>The research project aims to develop fundamental understanding of novel twisting-enabled pop-up origami structures with multi-stability. Practical applications of origami pop-up structures require a canopy and connected multiple origami rings to form a functional continuous face, which limits the accessibility of folding paths. This research will study how interactions among origami rings will affect folding and unfolding and provide understanding and identify the rules to design folding paths to overcome constraints imposed by these interactions. The research will yield knowledge about the energy landscape of origami rings and the stability of different states. Such understanding will facilitate the design of novel twisting-enabled pop-up and self-assembled structures with multi-stability. <br/><br/>Broader Impacts: <br/>This research project could enable a new class of origami structures with great potential for future applications. The proposed Origami design with rapid pop-up and self-assembly could greatly increase transportation efficiency of masks during the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. Moreover, the proposed origami concept can be readily applied to design other personal protection equipment such as eyewear, gowns, etc. It could also lead to new origami structures that are highly desirable in many demanding applications such as national security and human health. The research will increase the public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology and encourage the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM through integration of the research with carefully designed educational tasks and by integrating the advanced material research from the project into course development in existing undergraduate and high-level graduate courses.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project is to explore the fundamental mechanisms that can enable the rapid transformation of pop-up origami structures from a 2D extremely packed state to a 3D state. The fundamental understandings can be employed to design a new generation of 3D active thin shell structures, such as medical masks. Pop-up origami structures have been used in some daily consumer products. In these products, the structure can change from one small fully packed near-2D shape to a large 3D shape, through the transition of the multistable states of the origami structure. Inspired by the mechanism of pop-up structures, the proposed work will establish fundamental understandings and mechanics-guide design of origami-based extremely-packed multi-stable and self-assembled pop-up structures for medical masks, which has not been explored before. Once applying an actuation (such as a small force) to overcome the energy barrier, the structure can self-assemble and pop up from a small-volume extremely-packed 2D shape to a 3D shape, such as a full-size mask. The initial fully extremely packed shape can facilitate easy transportation and portability. For example, a dozen of masks could be folded and packed into the size of a gum pack.

This work has experimentally investigated the foldability of the ring origami structures and developed mechanics-guided design of origami-based multi-stable pop-up structures. The principle in such pop-up origami structures was studied with the hypothesis that the transition between two stable states is facilitated by a twisting deformation. Different ring geometries including circular, elliptical, rectangular, and triangular shapes were investigated to understand how the geometry can affect the folding/deployment paths. Based on the learned principle, extremely-packed multi-stable and self-assembled pop-up structures with the desired face-mask geometry are designed. This collaborative research project also provides the training to multiple postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students in structural stability analysis.
